Caption: The first copies of Dear New York have arrived. This one is deeply personal; holding it in my hand is like holding three years of my life. it opens with a longform HONY story‚Äî think Tanqueray, think Detra, think Venus‚Äî except this time it‚Äôs the story of my own attempt to capture the people of this city. The book then expands into four hundred full-color portraits and stories. Unlike previous Humans of New York books: 75 percent of these stories have not been shared online. Dear New York was lovingly created to be the most special thing that‚Äôs ever come out of Humans of New York. It will make you think, it will make you laugh, it will make you cry. It‚Äôs my love letter to this city, and I can‚Äôt wait to share it with you this October. But if you could do me a favor: if you think you‚Äôll be getting Dear New York this fall, consider locking in your order now. Preorders have never been more crucial to helping launch a book into the world. The book has yet to be heavily discounted, but I know Amazon and Barnes and Noble specifically will retroactively apply the inevitable future discounts to your order. Thanks everyone! Link in bio.

Caption: ‚ÄúHer name is Rita. It comes from a poem by a well-known poet of Palestine. It‚Äôs a song that I used to sing, and my wife loves it too. So Rita is a product of love between me and my wife. I haven‚Äôt seen either of them in a year and a half. When the border opened last year, I sent them both out of the country. I hold a Master‚Äôs degree in Burns, Plastic and Reconstructive Surgery‚Äîand these skills are deeply needed in Gaza. So I chose to stay behind. Now the border is closed, and I couldn‚Äôt leave if I wanted to. I do my best to talk to Rita on WhatsApp every day. I‚Äôll ask about kindergarten, and her swimming lessons. I‚Äôll look at her latest drawings, and try to encourage her. But that‚Äôs it; I‚Äôm a WhatsApp father only. A few days ago she was ignoring me a bit, so I asked: ‚ÄòWhy don‚Äôt you talk to me?‚Äô She told me: ‚ÄòI feel like I forgot you a little bit.‚Äô My wife jumped in, and said: ‚ÄòNo, no, she‚Äôs kidding.‚Äô But I said: ‚ÄòShe doesn‚Äôt need to be kidding. She‚Äôs saying the truth.‚Äô I‚Äôve been gone most of her life. First with my studies in England, and now with this separation. I do feel guilty, yes. But if I had left, I‚Äôd feel even more guilty. There‚Äôd be a crack in my heart. It would come to me in my nightmares, every time I saw the suffering of my people. The first stage of this genocide was to destroy the health infrastructure, so there‚Äôd be no refuge for the dying. I happen to be part of an organization, Doctors Without Borders, with big abilities and big principles. I knew that if we worked together, and made the right decisions, and did the right things‚Äîwe‚Äôd be able to provide comfort to countless people. And that‚Äôs what we‚Äôve done. I‚Äôve co-managed a team that built a field hospital with 120 beds, and three surgical theaters running 24 hours. This is something I‚Äôll be proud of for years and years. And I hope one day Rita will understand. I‚Äôll ask her to read books and watch documentaries about the genocide. I‚Äôll ask her to understand that I couldn‚Äôt close my eyes to the suffering of our people. We must resist. And how do we resist? By existing. And how do we exist? By having a value. And in our family, our value is to serve others, more than we serve ourselves.‚Äù

ImageLabels: img1 | img2 | img3 | img4 | img5 | img6 | img7
Caption: ‚ÄúThe last thing I heard was the voice of my children playing, then everything went black. When I opened my eyes I thought I‚Äôd gone blind. I couldn‚Äôt see anything. I could no longer hear their voices. I checked to see if my wife was alive. Her back and legs were fractured, but she was alive. So I turned on the light of my phone and tried to find the children. My three-year-old daughter Julia was calling to me from beneath the rubble: ‚ÄòBaba, Baba, where are you?‚Äô I carried her to a safe place then went back for my second son Kareem. He had severe head trauma. He was in a trance. He kept saying: ‚ÄòI‚Äôm sorry Mama. Please don‚Äôt blame me. I‚Äôm sorry.‚Äô When I brought them to the hospital, I refused to let my colleagues deal with their injuries. I dealt with them alone. I did the dressing. I removed the sutures. I wanted them to feel: ‚ÄòOur dad is taking care of us, maybe he can still protect us. Maybe he‚Äôs still our hero.‚Äô We‚Äôre doing OK, I guess. My wife is in a wheelchair now; she can‚Äôt walk. So I‚Äôm everyone‚Äôs caregiver. The children‚Äôs wounds are healing slowly. But there is a big problem with their brain. They cannot eat well, cannot talk well. Julia is still waking in the night and screaming. Every time she hears a rocket she starts trembling and crying. I used to tell her: ‚ÄòDon‚Äôt worry. They‚Äôre not targeting us.‚Äô It‚Äôs a myth that all of us in Gaza tell our children. But it doesn‚Äôt work anymore; she knows that it‚Äôs a lie.  I‚Äôm trying to keep myself together, so they can still see me as their hero. But no, I am not strong now. I‚Äôm weak. I‚Äôm not eating well. I used to wear better clothes. I‚Äôm not OK. There‚Äôs so much fear. Fear that they will never recover. If there‚Äôs another strike, even near us, they will lose their mind. You understand me? And I have so much guilt, because I‚Äôm the reason we stayed. We had a chance to leave Gaza, one year ago. But I refused. Because I love my people. I love my patients, so I chose to stay.  But I regret all of it. My children had the right to live their life. Not this life I chose for them. I‚Äôm not okay. I didn‚Äôt do well with my children. I didn‚Äôt save them or protect them. We used to be a beautiful family.  But now, I don‚Äôt know.‚Äù

‚ÄúI cannot forget a minute of that day. When I tell you this, it is like I‚Äôm seeing it in front of my face on a movie screen. At 3 AM drones appeared outside the windows of the hospital. Most of my colleagues had already fled. I forgive all of them; few beliefs can override the desire to save one‚Äôs own soul. But I could not leave. There were hundreds of patients, and few medical staff remaining. If the last of us left, these patients would have died. The hospital staff assembled in the lobby where we were stripped, handcuffed, blindfolded, and marched into the freezing night. Beneath my blindfold I could see hundreds of fighters with machine guns. I could hear the screams of my colleagues being beaten. My fear was so high I was close to cardiac arrest. Someone speaking weak Arabic put a gun to my head and told me I‚Äôd never see my children again. He asked: ‚ÄòWhere is Hamas? Where are the Hostages?‚Äô I told him: ‚ÄòI‚Äôm just a nurse; I disagree entirely with October 7th.‚Äô But these guys did not care. They beat us all. The lorries came to transport us to the detention center. At the door of the lorry stood the strongest of their fighters, body-builders. And before entering each detainee received the three hardest punches we will ever receive in our lives. When we arrived we were made to lie on the ground, and they put dogs on us. The dogs had muzzles, but we could not see through our blindfolds. All around me was barking and screaming; I thought my colleagues were being eaten. I was detained for several weeks. The conditions were so bad I prayed to die. One of the prison guards, exactly one, I can accept as my neighbor. The rest had hatred in their eyes. Some spoke English; so I tried to reason with them. I pointed out that half of the detainees had debilitating medical conditions. Some were eighty years old. One man was mentally incapacitated. I asked the guards: ‚ÄòHow could these people possibly be Hamas?‚Äô But for every claim‚Äîthey‚Äôd have a response. Some reason all of us were guilty. Even when I said: ‚ÄòI‚Äôm a nurse,‚Äô they replied: ‚ÄòOh, so you treated terrorists.‚Äô To them, every Palestinian deserves to suffer. And nothing you say‚Äînothing‚Äî will convince them otherwise.‚Äù

ImageLabels: img1 | img2 | img3 | img4 | img5 | img6 | img7
Caption: When I tried to interview Marwa, the internet in Gaza was so bad I couldn‚Äôt hear half of her words. She then sent me a written follow-up, which was so moving, and so beautifully written, that I‚Äôve ditched the interview altogether and am including it here in full: ‚ÄúIsrael bombed our house into a pile of rubble and dust. Everyone in it‚Äî my mother, my father, my four sisters, my brother, my baby niece‚Äî became a memory in the same instant. During the war, the home had become our lifeline. Comfort wasn‚Äôt always in words. It was in a shared cup of tea in the dark. It was my mother holding our hands, her presence a silent promise that we were not alone. It was my sisters distracting the children with stories. We would huddle together, our physical closeness a shield against the terrifying sounds outside. It‚Äôs probably a mercy that the house is now gone, because I don‚Äôt think my heart could bear to see the physical emptiness of the rooms where so much life once existed. It‚Äôs the ‚Äòunimportant‚Äô moments, the background noise of a living family, that I miss the most. I miss the sound of my father‚Äôs key in the door at the end of the day. I miss my mother‚Äôs hand on my forehead, checking for a fever that wasn‚Äôt there, just out of habit. I miss arguing with Nour about politics and then laughing about it two minutes later. I miss Mona‚Äôs quiet smile from across the room, a look that says: ‚ÄòI understand. I miss Ayat bursting into my room to show me a funny video. I miss the boys debating which one of them was the better gamer. Where all that beautiful noise used to be‚Äîthere is nothing but profound silence. If I had one more moment with each of them, I would simply say: ‚ÄòThank you.‚Äô To my father: ‚ÄòThank you for believing in me more than I ever believed in myself.‚Äô To my mother: ‚ÄòThank you for every silent sacrifice I was too young or too busy to notice.‚Äô To my sisters and brothers: ‚ÄòThank you for being the irreplaceable pieces of my childhood and my heart.‚Äô And if I could sit all of them together one more time, the whole family, I would say to them: ‚ÄòI see you. I see everything you did for me, for us. And I am so incredibly grateful.‚Äù

‚ÄúAll day I am thinking: your son, your son. You need to do something for your son. Yazan is not a normal boy, he‚Äôs very disabled. But he‚Äôs the most precious thing I‚Äôve got. Before the war he was improving so much. He was going to therapy. He was making good eye contact. He‚Äôs very shy, he cannot express his feelings. But I would take him to visit the neighbors and everyone loved him. He‚Äôs a lovely boy: he holds my head, he kisses my cheeks. Right before the war we had a surgery on his legs. At that time he was five years old. When the doctors removed his casts I brought him home from the hospital, and I told my daughters and my wife to close their eyes. When they opened their eyes again, Yazan was walking. We‚Äôll never forget this moment; we had so much hope that he‚Äôd be a normal boy. But all the clinics have been closed now for two years. He‚Äôs had no therapy. Nothing has been done for him, nothing. Now if he walks three steps he falls down. Before the war he‚Äôd started to make sentences with a few words: ‚ÄòI need bread, I need water.‚Äô Now if he wants something, he‚Äôll just catch me by the arm and show me. And he‚Äôs doing this thing now, where he jerks his arms and legs. This is something we‚Äôve never seen before. We thought we would always go forward. We thought that he would be a normal boy. But now I am watching him deteriorate before my eyes. I have a good job; I work on a medical team. But still, I have no power. It takes all my power just to keep him from dying. Last year he got very bad diarrhea. There was no drinkable water. All of the pharmacies were empty. But I heard of a pharmacy six kilometers away with diarrhea medicine. I was so tired. No car, no fuel, no donkey cart. It was like horrible American action movie: there was bombing, shooting from tanks, shooting from helicopter. But I walked six kilometers, and I got him some medicine. And we managed to stop the diarrhea. Anything he needs, I will do. I have two hands. In one of these hands I carry all the problems of my work, all the problems of the war, raising my four daughters with no food, no water, no shelter, no electricity. And in the other hand, I carry Yazan.‚Äù üì∏ by @nouralsaqa

‚ÄúBefore the war I never thought of getting married‚Äî maybe after 30 or something. But when the war started my mind changed. Every night I am awakened by airstrikes. I live near the sea, and the helicopters are coming from the sea. Whenever I hear them, I am thinking: ‚ÄòWhat if this one is for me?‚Äù And if these shots are for me‚Äîhow is it going to feel?‚Äô A few months ago my uncles family‚Äîthey died, to the very last, including the baby. They were sheltering in a school that got bombed. They say when something like that happens, you don‚Äôt feel anything. So if it happens to me, this is what I hope. But sometimes you get trapped beneath the rubble. And it takes a long time to die. It‚Äôs very scary to think about. For the first time in my life I‚Äôve started to feel like I need someone‚Äî someone to tell me that everything‚Äôs going to be okay. Four months ago I became engaged. Her name is Lama. She‚Äôs the sister of my best friend Kareem, who was killed in a bombing last year. I was driving to her house today. I‚Äôd put on jeans, and was smelling very good, and I started thinking: ‚ÄòMaybe I shouldn‚Äôt be so happy. Because things are so bad for everyone.‚Äô But if I‚Äôm being honest, we are very happy. It is maybe even better than being in love in a normal situation. Sometimes when I wake up from the airstrikes: I‚Äôll send her a very sweet message: ‚ÄòI hope you are very good,‚Äô and so on. This is something that is nothing during normal times. But it‚Äôs a bit different when you are checking if someone is alive. All these things, which used to seem like nothing, are everything to us now. I visit her two or three times a week. Every time I go to her house, we have like five minutes or so.  If she‚Äôs upset about Kareem, upset about the situation, afraid of the missiles, I‚Äôll calm her down. I‚Äôll give her a hug. It‚Äôs a very great feeling, honestly. I don‚Äôt know how to describe it. It‚Äôs not going to stop bullets, or bombs, but it makes you feel safe. By that I mean, at least I‚Äôm with her and she‚Äôs with me. If something happens to me, it is going to happen to her. So we going to be in the same situation. We will live together, or we will die together. And just knowing this, it makes me feel safe.‚Äù

‚ÄúI cannot cry. Before the war‚Äî any little thing, it would make me cry. But now I cannot make myself. I want to but I can‚Äôt, even when my heart is breaking. I used to be a schoolteacher; I love children. But now I see them walking in the streets with no shoes. They come into our clinic and you can see how tired they are. Some of them are mutilated: they‚Äôve lost a leg, or an arm. You see children crying because they cannot walk again. Yes, there is a lot of children like this now. But even the ones who aren‚Äôt injured are changing. Before the war it was not normal to find a child who wasn‚Äôt in school. There were organizations that would find the parents and force them to enroll. But now Gaza‚Äôs children haven‚Äôt been to school in two years. They‚Äôre changing. They‚Äôre beginning to think: ‚ÄòI will never go to school. I will just work to bring my family food or water.‚Äô Even my own daughter; she‚Äôs twelve years old. She was a leader in school and she dreamed to be a doctor. She has a cousin in Canada, the same age. They have video calls, and my daughter can see the difference. She sees how far behind she‚Äôs fallen, and recently she told me: ‚ÄòI won‚Äôt be a doctor anymore.‚Äô This broke my heart, but still, I could not cry. It‚Äôs like something is blocked in me. I don‚Äôt share my pain with anyone. I don‚Äôt share with my husband. I don‚Äôt share with my mother, or my father, or my sister. Because all these people come to me to feel safe. A few months ago when they bombed the house of my husband‚Äôs family‚ÄîI went to collect the body parts. It was too difficult for my husband. He lost fifteen members of his family that day. His mother, his father, his brother, were beneath the rubble. So I went. I had to start looking: this is the head for who? This arm, this leg, is for who? Afterwards I sat alone, and I tried to cry. I felt that if only I could cry, I will feel better. I will feel less full. But even then, I could not. I have a colleague in the work, who tells me: ‚ÄòKholoud, after the war, you are going to collapse. Because you do not cry.‚Äô‚Äù üì∏ @nouralsaqa

‚ÄúMy whole life people have said to me: ‚ÄòYou are too kind, too sensitive.‚Äô When I interviewed for a schoolteacher position, the principal told me: ‚ÄòYou will never be able to control the students.‚Äô Because of this I built in my mind that I‚Äôm not a very strong person, you know? I decided to focus on my house, my family, my children. When the war started I was working as a data encoder; I spent all day on the laptop. But Doctors Without Borders said to me: ‚ÄòKholoud, there is no one left to ask. We need you to help organize our operations in the North.‚Äô And I‚Äôve done it. I organized a network of people on the ground. Everyone in the organization knows me now, respects me. And I‚Äôve done all of this while raising four children, and another four children who lost their parents. In December we spent fifteen days on the street because there were too many bombs. Nobody could sleep safely inside. I ate nothing during this time, zero. I just drank some water every two days. We were sheltering in a small corridor inside a school yard. My husband left us to look for food, and that‚Äôs when the bomb fell. When it falls close to you, you don‚Äôt hear anything. You just see the body parts flying through the air: the hand of someone, the leg of someone, the head of someone. My son comes to me and his face is blood. My daughter comes to me and she is clutching her chest. My other two children are holding their legs; I can‚Äôt tell how they are injured. There was no hospital left in Gaza City, so I brought them back to our house. Our neighbor is a doctor, so I asked him to come over. We discovered that one of my children had shrapnel in the head. The other three in the leg. There was no anesthesia, no stitches. We put something in the children‚Äôs mouth, and I held them down while he removed the shrapnel with the kitchen knife. You cannot imagine how the children were screaming. But we removed the shrapnel. And when we finished, I took the knife, and removed the shrapnel from my own leg. ‚ÄòToo kind, too sensitive.‚Äô I heard this my entire life. But I can tell you: another person lives inside you. And if the world forces you, you will find her.‚Äù üì∏ @nouralsaqa

‚ÄúI‚Äôve closed my social media. From Gaza it‚Äôs all bad news: someone‚Äôs dying, someone‚Äôs been bombed, someone‚Äôs been displaced from their home. Then everywhere else in the world, you see things working so smoothly. Everyone is living their lives. Literally the smallest thing that they do: it makes me jealous. The smallest thing, like eating ice cream. This is my favorite food. And I‚Äôve gone two years without any ice cream. I don‚Äôt want to feel envious of anyone, so I‚Äôm trying not to see it. I‚Äôm still trying to treat myself in whatever small ways I can: like doing my hair, or maybe having henna dye on my hands. After work I will try to sit with my sisters, so we can connect, and say about our dreams. One of my dreams is for us all to live on an empty farm, a quiet place outside all the world. Two of our cousins have already passed away in a bombing. Four of my nieces and nephews were injured. I can‚Äôt lose anyone else. I can‚Äôt, I won‚Äôt be able to take it. My family is everything to me. Right now our home is partially destroyed, but we are still living in it. Because we don‚Äôt have anywhere else to go. Every day when I come home from work, my two-year old niece is waiting for me at the front door. Her name is Hanan; it means kindness. And when she hugs me it‚Äôs like a battery has charged in my heart. Literally all of her life has been in this war. Whenever she hears the sound of a plane, she covers her ears and says: ‚ÄòBoom! Boom! Boom!‚Äô She never goes anywhere. She never meets new people. We are her entire world. We do everything we can to protect her, to give her a childhood. Her birthday was two weeks ago. We had dancing all night. There was bombing all around us, but we just turned up the volume and tried to disconnect from all the noise. Sugar is impossible to get in Gaza now; but we gathered all the sugar we could. Everyone contributed. And with this sugar we made a cake, and cinnamon rolls, and sweet tea with mint. Hanan eats nothing but canned food; no snacks, no treats. So when she saw that cake, she started to scream. All the children started to scream; you can‚Äôt imagine their joy. It was maybe my best moment ever, in all of the war.‚Äù

‚ÄúMy name is Weam. It‚Äôs a beautiful name for me, because my mother gave it to me. She died of cancer when I was eight years old‚Äî so I love my name, because my mom loved it. It‚Äôs also perfect for me because it means ‚Äòpeace, love, and harmony.‚Äô And everyone who meets me says that I‚Äôm positive energy shining everywhere. I‚Äôm a team leader for twenty-three pharmacists. ‚ÄòThe pharma army,‚Äô we call it. Ask anyone: we are the happiest team in the hospital. After we start our morning meeting, I‚Äôll put on a bit of music for everyone. If they want to dance, they can dance. If they want to sing, they can sing. We are working 24 hours, seven days a week without stopping. They are under so much stress, all the time. There are always mass casualty incidents. And everyone in Gaza is living their own nightmare: with the bombings, the displacements, the hunger. So I‚Äôm just trying to make it easier for them. When I help others, it feels like I‚Äôm doing something right, that I‚Äôm still useful in this life. In Islam, if you speak a good word to someone else, it is also a good thing for you. So if someone smiles, and says: ‚ÄòGood job, you did it, you survived another day.‚Äô This is a big deal for us. So I try to keep a smile from ear to ear. But on the inside, no. I am not happy at all. I haven‚Äôt slept for more than three hours since the war began. We are all screwed up in this world. Even if you are still alive in this moment, maybe in five minutes you will die. The smallest spark of light can be destroyed in the blink of an eye. How can anyone be happy when they are surrounded by so much death? But there is something that my mother said to me, right before she died. It‚Äôs the only memory that I have of her. She told me: ‚ÄòWeam, please keep that smile on your face. Because everyone loves your smile.‚Äô So that‚Äôs what I‚Äôm trying to do. I‚Äôm trying. You will find that even when I‚Äôm crying, I am smiling.‚Äù

‚ÄúThe shift started like any other. I was making my rounds when around 2 pm I heard a bombing; it sounded very close. My family lives relatively near the hospital. Usually, when a bombing is that close, I would call them immediately. But on that day I didn‚Äôt call. I don‚Äôt know why. Maybe I‚Äôd grown desensitized. But after an hour I began to notice that the nurses were acting shifty around me. I was summoned to a case in the emergency room, and as we were walking down the hallway, one of the nurses asked if I‚Äôd heard from my family. That‚Äôs when I knew. I started running to the ER. The first person I found was my father. He‚Äôd been in the explosion area; he was stunned. My sister was next to him, she was also in shock. I asked about my mother and the nurse told me that she was in the ICU. It wasn‚Äôt true. But that‚Äôs what he told me, so he could get me alone. The ICU is three floors up from the ER, so I immediately began running up the stairs. The nurse ran after me. We passed the first floor, the second floor, and then he stopped me forcefully. He told me: ‚ÄòI‚Äôm sorry. I didn‚Äôt know how to tell you. But your mother is deceased.‚Äô I fell to the floor. And I can‚Äôt remember everything here, I was in shock. But they brought me to the forensics room and led me to a giant, white bag. I unzipped it. And I saw her face. She looked as good as alive. She had bled out through her legs, so her face was untouched. And I wanted so bad to kiss her in that moment. So I kissed her. And I began to hug her. But they pulled me away and they covered her again. I‚Äôm sorry. I‚Äôm sorry for the tears. But this is the first time I‚Äôve talked to anyone about this. I have to be strong for my family. Especially because my father is a paraplegic now; it‚Äôs a lot of responsibility. I need to be the emotional sponge for everyone else. That‚Äôs my focus now: caring for my father, my siblings, my patients. I want to help other people, and be a good Muslim. It‚Äôs not that deep. I just have to believe that she‚Äôs in a better place. And if I fulfill my responsibilities, then we will meet again. It‚Äôs what I have to believe. It‚Äôs all the relief I can get.‚Äù (2/2)

‚ÄúWe had one chance to leave Gaza, early in the war. At that time our lives had grown very difficult. We‚Äôd been displaced. We sat down and had a family discussion, and the consensus in the family was not to leave. We‚Äôd just learned that our house was still standing, so we thought: ‚ÄòWe‚Äôre luckier than others.‚Äô One month later the Philadelphi corridor was closed, and the option to leave was exhausted. But we still thought we would be OK. We thought the war would end soon, as we think now, as we thought a year ago, as we thought two years ago. And at least we were together. Our family has always been extremely close. I care for my patients, I care for my friends, but not the way I care for my family. Especially my mother. All people say that their mother is a saint, but she was actually a saint. She hated no one. She loved everyone. When I was a child she worked as a schoolteacher, and her school was next to mine, so in the mornings we would walk to school together. I don‚Äôt know why I remember this‚Äîbut she‚Äôd always walk between me and the sun. So that I could stand in her shadow. It‚Äôs a simple memory, but it means a lot to me. I was always the most attached to her. Maybe everyone in our family feels the same way, but this is my feeling. I told jokes only for her, so that she would laugh. I specialized in medicine just to make her happy. I was a resilient teenager. I wanted to be a writer. But she confronted me. She told me: ‚ÄòLife on Earth is a short journey, and you should help people. Because we believe in God. And we believe there is more than just this life.‚Äô Everything, all the things I have done, I have done to please her. And I let her down. I let her down. Because it was my decision. Three days before she was killed, I evacuated her to a safer place. And the safer place got bombed.‚Äù (1/2)

‚ÄúWhen I entered Gaza the Israeli military had a rule: I was only allowed to bring in seven pounds of food. As I was weighing out protein bars, trying to get under the limit, I said to my husband: ‚ÄòHow sinister is this?‚Äô I‚Äôm a humanitarian aid worker. Why would there even be a limit on food? I‚Äôve worked in many places with extreme hunger, but what‚Äôs so jarring in this context is how cruel it is, how deliberate. I was in Gaza for two months; there‚Äôs no way to describe the horror of what‚Äôs happening. And I say this as a pediatric ICU doctor who sees children die as part of my work. Among our own staff we have doctors and nurses who are trying to treat patients while hungry, exhausted. They‚Äôre living in tents. Some of them have lost fifteen, twenty members of their families. In the hospital there are kids maimed by airstrikes: missing arms, missing legs, third degree burns. Often there‚Äôs not enough pain medication. But the children are not screaming about the pain, they‚Äôre screaming: ‚ÄòI‚Äôm hungry! I‚Äôm hungry!‚Äù I hate to only focus on the kids, because nobody should be starving. But the kids, it just haunts you in a different way. When my two months were finished, I didn‚Äôt want to leave. It‚Äôs a feeling I haven‚Äôt experienced in nearly twenty years of humanitarian assignments. But I felt ashamed. Ashamed to leave my Palestinian colleagues, who were some of the most beautiful and compassionate people that I‚Äôve ever met. I was ashamed as an American, as a human being, that we‚Äôve been unable to stop something that is so clearly a genocide. I remember when our bus pulled out of the buffer zone. Out the window on one side I could see Rafah, which was nothing but rubble. On the other side was lush, green Israel. When we exited the gate, the first thing I saw was a group of Israeli soldiers, sitting at a table, eating lunch. I‚Äôve never felt so nauseous seeing a table full of food.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe were young when we had her. I was twenty-three, the mother was twenty; we weren‚Äôt planning to have kids yet. I don‚Äôt want to say the relationship fell apart because of our daughter. It was mostly us. We were going through a stressful time: I‚Äôd just lost my mother, she‚Äôd just lost her grandmother. We were going through an eviction and had to move into a shelter. We just handled our stress in different ways. She dealt with it by wanting to be young and dumb and free. We were arguing about everything, and I‚Äôm not good at arguing. I don‚Äôt like confrontation. I get agitated, antsy. Every time there was an argument, I‚Äôd get so angry that I‚Äôd have to leave the facility to get some air. I‚Äôve been that way since childhood. My mom and my dad were heavy addicts; they lost custody of me when I was four. I grew up in programs. I didn‚Äôt have nobody to show me affection. And it made me angry, I was an angry kid. I saw that other people had love, and understood it, and to be honest, I wasn‚Äôt okay with it. There are times where I still feel like that, sometimes even now as a father. But every time I look at her it goes away. It went away the moment she was born. When you held your first kid, did you see a glow around them? Did you ever see a glow? Because I saw a glow. And I felt it. It was like, holy shit.  I wanted to cry the first time I felt it, because I wasn‚Äôt sure what it was. I was confused. But as it gradually grew on me, I was like: OK, so this is what love is. And it felt beautiful. It made me want to be better. I don‚Äôt want my daughter seeing the side of me from when I was young and didn‚Äôt know how to cope with my anger. Right now I have her every day after school. There‚Äôs a counselor at her school: Mr. Gonzalez. I go to see him once, sometimes twice a week. He‚Äôs been very helpful. He‚Äôs teaching me how to cope with life, how to handle arguments with my baby‚Äôs mother. Now if she texts me twenty paragraphs about things that happened six years ago, I don‚Äôt fight back. I just don‚Äôt respond, until it‚Äôs time to get the baby.‚Äù

Happy Ganesh Chaturthi! 

This Hindu festival honors Lord Ganesha, the remover of obstacles and the god of wisdom and prosperity. Celebrated with immense devotion across India, families and communities install beautifully crafted idols of Ganesha in their homes and public spaces.

In this particular part of India, thousands of devotees from all over Mumbai come to immerse idols of Genesha in the Arabian Sea.

In the second picture, my camera happened to get immersed in water and the roll of film was damaged‚Ä¶but that‚Äôs another story!

A few of the wonderful Tibetans I met on my travels in Eastern Tibet.

1st image: Monastery cook, Litang, 2001.
2nd image: Shoeshine Boy, Lhasa, 2000.
3rd image: Boy in Litang holds a Yak skull. 2005.
Celebrating World Photography Day, an Afghan man sits with his old box camera, used to take portraits on the street. Kabul, Afghanistan, 1992
Television Assembly line. Bangalore, India, 1996.
Barber shop, Bamiyan Province, Afghanistan, 2006.

Remembering the great Italian photographer, Gianni Berengo Gardin, 1930-2025. A true master of photography whose work and spirit inspired us all. 

His legacy will continue to live on through his timeless images. Rest in peace.
A cat rests by a book and a sunny window in Karelia, 2012.
Young Tibetan nomad boy, 2005.
Bugti tribesmen partake in the intricate art of self-grooming. Dera Bugti, Balochistan, Pakistan, 1980.

A young girl is carrying a stone to her family‚Äôs home. I was moved by the expression on her face as she attempted to smile. Her father had asked her to bring the stone home from his workplace. 

Rajasthan, India, 2008.
This 2500-year-old temple in South India is one of the most stunning in the world! Meenakshi Amman Temple, Madurai, India, 2019.
These Kolkata laborers are joined in sleep next to a poster of Shiva immersed in his deep meditation or Yoga Nidra. India, 1996.
Two women huddled under an umbrella. Panjim, Goa, India, 1978.
Girl stands in flood water, covered in duckweed, in front of her home, Java, Indonesia, 1983.

A pet dog tries to escape the monsoon floodwaters after his owner let him outside in Porbandar, India, 1983. After realizing he had nowhere to go, a bark signaled the homeowner to let him back inside.

Caption: Big News üëÄ

If anxiety was a dog üòÖ

I met this ADORABLE four-month old puppy named Frankie. 

Her mama @emzlabyrinth told me that she‚Äôs VERY loving, but also VERY anxious. 

Frankie kept running to hide in between her parents‚Äô legs lol

Emily wasn‚Äôt sure if we could get any good photos of her pup‚Ä¶ but she welcomed me to try. 

(And you know I love a good challenge)

So we took it very slow, and sure enough, Frankie started to warm up to the camera. 

And once she was safe in her dad‚Äôs arms, she let her expressions shine lol

What do you think - did we pull it off? 

‚Äî

üìç Outside of BC Place, Vancouver BC

‚Äî
Hashtags: streetphotography | streetphotographer | strangerportraits | dogportraits | puppyportraits

Caption:
So many plot twists üòÇ

Okay this is probably one of my fave interactions so far lol. 

You might recall a few weeks ago I shared a photo on my stories of a couple at their wedding, with their dog in a tux in the middle. ü§µ‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è

I didn‚Äôt get to meet their dog that day‚Ä¶ but luckily, I spotted them in the crowd at @TheDayOfTheDog festival and approached them. 

That‚Äôs when I met Hank - a certified good boy with a heart of gold. üíõ

When Ryan and Jamie got him, they thought he was 100% Cockapoo. 

Turns out, he‚Äôs a unique mix of a bunch of different breeds (which makes him even cuter!) 

Here‚Äôs some fun facts about Hank: 
üéÇ Almost 3 years old
üêæ Mix: Cockapoo, Maltese, Havanese, Fox Terrier
üê∫ Is convinced he‚Äôs a wolf
‚úàÔ∏è Small enough to travel in the plane
üçè Food motivated (except for apple treats lol)

Usually when I do street portraits and photograph dogs, it‚Äôs a lot quieter.

But this all went down in the middle of a busy crowd, which means this interaction went off the rails many times üòÇ 

But that‚Äôs okay! I had a smile on my face the whole time. 

And those howls at the end? 

ü´†ü´†ü´†ü´†

So adorable lol. 

I‚Äôm so glad I ran into you guys again - and thanks for letting me snap your photos! üôè

@jamiehartwell.pt @rhealey1988

===

P.S. I tried to find the dog in the Tutu (at 0:29) after I was done photographing Hank, but it was so busy that I couldn‚Äôt find her. 

If she (or her owner) happens to read this, send me a message! I owe you a photo üò≠

===

üìç Yaletown, Vancouver BC

===

üì∏ CAMERA GEAR USED: ‚Ä®Sony A7CII
Sony 28-70mm f/2.0
Shortstache Everyday Filter

Meet Tofu - An American Eskimo pup ‚ùÑÔ∏è

I was at @TheDayofTheDog event in Yaletown when Chanel came up and said hello. 

These events are always crazy (in a good way), with tons of dogs, people and excitement‚Ä¶ so I thought I could blend in with the crowd. 

But I guess standing there with a @sonyalpha camera, a huge smile and bright @vessi shoes kinda gave me away. üòÇ

That‚Äôs when she introduced me to her sister Princess - and her dog, Tofu (@hello.tofu).

Tofu is a six-year old American Eskimo pup. ‚ùÑÔ∏è

He loves chicken, sleeping, swimming and posing for the camera. 

Tofu also LOVES people. He gets to hang out in an office all day, and greets everyone as they walk by. 

But dogs? He‚Äôs a little picky (depending on the breed). üòÇ

During our photoshoot, Tofu kept running up to the camera for his close-up, so I had to include one (even if it‚Äôs a little out of focus lol). 

But my fave shot came near the end. 

We were trying to get Tofu to smile, but he kept giving us this face: üòê

(Understandable, as he was probably getting sick of people calling him cute all day lol)

But when they picked him up, and gave him a big kiss, he let out the BIGGEST smile. 

Thanks for saying hi that day, @imyourprincess_ & @chaneldazo!

Was a pleasure to meet all three of you. üôè

===

Caption:
Sneak peek from @thedayofthedog üëÄ

Yesterday was the Day of the Dog event in Vancouver, and WOW, what a turnout! 

I photographed SOOOO many pups this year, definitely a new record lol.

What‚Äôs even crazier? How much the tables have turned w/ this project. 

For the first time ever, I barely had to approach anyone...

Because most people I met walked up to ME to say hi first. üòÖ

I seriously couldn‚Äôt believe it lol

But man oh man, am I ever grateful. ü•π

What an amazing community we‚Äôve built here. 

So many more photos & stories to come! 

‚Äî

üëã P.S. If I photographed your dog yesterday, send me a DM so I can send you the photos!

Kitsilano

This dog is a badass üí™

Met Kiefer and Nika chilling in the shade in Kitsilano on a hot summer‚Äôs day. Nika was standing there, looking like she owned the block. 

Nika is a 1-year-old husky mix with more energy than my camera battery. 

She loves spending her time at the beach chasing waves, sunsets and other dogs. 

She was such a great little model - and just look at that tongue! 

Plus she loved the smell of my @sonyalpha A7CII üòÇ 

And as a bonus - a few minutes later we ran into Nika‚Äôs mom and got a quick photo of them together. 

Thanks for letting me take your portraits! üôè

New Lease on Life üêæ

Met Jessa and her superstar pup Tina in Yaletown recently. 

Tina‚Äôs a 10.5-year-old husky/shepherd mix with a heart of gold and two brand new ACLs. 

She‚Äôs been with Jessa since puppyhood‚Äîmoved all the way from Winnipeg to Vancouver. 

‚ÄúBest decision ever‚Äù, Jessa says. 

Tina keeps her active, keeps her smiling, and makes the city feel friendlier. 

Tina nailed her model pose (and her big paw trick). 

She was such a fantastic model, so she got lots of treats that day. 

Matching smiles, a few kisses, and a whole lot of love. 

Jessa‚Äôs got the best sidekick. 

And Tina? She‚Äôs got the best mom. 

Thanks for letting me take your portraits, @jessawmitchell üôè

Saved from a Puppy Mill ‚ù§Ô∏è‚Äçü©π

I met this little angel named Molly in Vancouver recently. 

This dog is a 10-year old Toy Poodle rescue who spent most of her life in a puppy mill. 

Now she spends her days comfortably at home, patiently waiting for her parents to get off work so they can explore the city together. üåá

Molly enjoys the simple things in life‚Ä¶

Sniffing the grass, walking in the shade and taking in the sights of the city. 

Molly wasn‚Äôt fond of people or pets when they first adopted her, but she‚Äôs made a ton of progress in the last six months, now she‚Äôs confident and social. üí™

This pup doesn‚Äôt bark, and stays quiet as a mouse. üê≠

Molly is missing her teeth, so her tongue just kinda hangs out on the side. 

She doesn‚Äôt seem to mind though‚Ä¶ plus I think it adds character to her already cute demeanour. üòú

Even random people have stopped their car in traffic to yell out to say how much they love her. 

I‚Äôm glad this pup will get to spend the rest of her days feeling loved & appreciated. ‚ù§Ô∏è

@____k_kx_l

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs my soulmate‚Äù ü•π

I was on Commercial Drive when I saw this little dog in a bow-tie as big as his head.

That‚Äôs when I met Lilly, Monica (@Shmiligan), and Cheese (@Cheesethemighty). 

Yes, Cheese üßÄ

Cheese is a four year old Chihuahua with calm confidence. 

Lilly told me that Cheese has ‚ÄúBDE‚Äù

Big Dog Energy üòÇ

And she was right, because despite all the craziness of the event, Cheese seemed totally chill and unbothered. 

He didn‚Äôt have a care in the world, even when a total stranger was taking his portrait. 

When I noticed him shaking a little bit, Lilly said he‚Äôs just on vibrate mode lol üòÇ

Lilly describes this little man as her soul mate, which makes sense because you can clearly see the love they have for one another.

This dog recognized me ü•∫

This interaction is definitely special. 

Diana and I were about to head home after a long day of photographing dogs downtown.

But we both forgot where I parked üòÇ

And as we were wandering around looking for my car, this beautiful Border Collie was crossing the street in front of us. 

Diana and I were mid-conversation, and out of nowhere this dog started going crazy and pulling frantically towards us. 

I wasn‚Äôt ready to take more photos, and my battery was at 5% lol

But as soon as I saw how excited this dog was, I couldn‚Äôt say no. ü•π

That‚Äôs when I met Carlotta (@carlottacrestanello) and Zoey (@zoeysauce_bordercollie). 

Zoey is a 5 year old Border Collie who is very smart, super expressive (and VERY sassy lol). 

Carlotta was having a pretty rough day, but seeing Zoey do happy dances put a big smile on her face. 

And once she saw the photos, she was happy to let me share them. 

Carlotta thinks Zoey recognized me since she watches my videos with Zoey laying next to her - so she may have recognized my voice. 

I‚Äôm still not used to getting recognized by people‚Ä¶

But being recognized by a dog?! 

That‚Äôs a life achievement that I‚Äôm very happy about. ü•π

Thanks for letting me snap your portraits, ladies! üôè

I was walking downtown with @dmespitia0922 when I spotted this ADORABLE little dog with fluffy ears and pretty eyelashes.

The dog‚Äôs name is Hoochu; a 7 year old mixed-breed rescue. 

I wish I could tell you what the breed of this dog is, but we‚Äôre not 100% sure since it was a rescue. 

(My guess is either Teddy Bear or Pokemon)

What we DO know is that Hoochu is super sweet, very gentle - and a big fan of my apple treats. 

What an unbelievably photogenic pup though! 

Thanks for letting me take your portraits, @hoochu.is.home!

Time passes, love remains üíõ

Heads up ‚Äî this post deals with the loss of family. 

Leo and I were both fighting back tears, so maybe skip this one if you‚Äôre not in the right head space for it.

===

Leo lit up in front of the camera. 

Warm. Playful. Kind. 

As we talked, Leo shared the meaning behind the tattoos‚Ä¶

Stories of family, identity, and grief. 

The symbol for ‚Äúequality‚Äù proudly inked on their neck.

Before we wrapped up, I asked if they had any advice for someone my age. 

About how to navigate the next chapter of life.

Their answer? ‚ÄúJust enjoy it. Time moves faster than you can imagine.‚Äù

I needed to hear that.

Leo (@maddoxleo) ‚Äî you‚Äôre a beautiful soul. 

Thank you for trusting me with your portrait. üíú

I was in Kitsilano when I spotted a girl riding a @onewheel with a VERY cute dog running next to her. 

So I called out to get her attention (in the most Canadian way possible lol) üá®üá¶

That‚Äôs when I met Marika (@marikasila) and Qavvik (@lil.wolverine).

This pup was an absolute PRO in front of the camera, so it didn‚Äôt surprise me when she said he‚Äôs a doggy influencer üòÇ Check out her page to see lots of cute videos of Qavvik.

While we were taking pictures, I noticed lots of people stopping to take photos of Qavvik. 

This pup was the centre of attention and he was LOVING it. 

And Marika? What a gem. She was rushing to get home to host an event, but was still happy to take a few minutes for photos. üíé

BTW If you‚Äôre interested in @onewheel‚Äôs, my friend @jessedriftwood has a ton of awesome videos about them. I don‚Äôt own one myself, but I‚Äôve rode them and they‚Äôre loads of fun. ü§ô

.

.
Hashtags: belfastireland | stylishwomen | streetportrait | portraitsshotz | streetphotographyhub | streetinterview | visitbelfast | ireland_gram | disabilityinclusion | streetpic | modelstrangers | humanpotrait | portraitfotografie | sonyalphaportrait | belfastcity

Caption:
It‚Äôs turned out to be a wonderful year for Anne since I stopped her outside Belfast City Hall back in January. 

Her @modelstrangers video went viral (over 40 million views on all social media platforms). Not only did it give my own Instagram page a big boost, but she has been offered many exciting opportunities.

She has become a celebrity of sorts around Belfast, being stopped by people who have thanked her for being an inspiration to them. She has also been asked to model for @kindredofireland and has even been signed with @acamodels! 

Not forgetting that just recently we appeared on @bbctheoneshow together. 

I can‚Äôt overstate how proud I am of her. 

One of the things I have noticed about Anne is that even though she is quite a shy and retiring person, who struggles like many of us with self-esteem, she is always open to trying new experiences and treats things outside of her comfort zone with a calm level-headedness and professionalism. 

Anne has proved that grace, beauty and intelligence know no age. She is so warm and friendly and kind, and she deserves all the good things that have happened to her. 

Thank you Anne for saying yes to me on that cold January afternoon. It was indeed meant to be. 
.
.
.

Everything about this man was just remarkable.

I admire people like him deeply. Since he was 13, he‚Äôs worked through storms, early mornings, and countless hard days, without ever really taking a break. Caption:
I still can‚Äôt believe they actually let me step onto the bridge of the @hurtigruten ship and meet the captain! üö¢ What made it even cooler was discovering that this time, the captain was a ‚Äòshe‚Äô, a powerful reminder that tough, big, and highly responsible jobs are led by incredible women too.

üôå Huge thanks to Hurtigruten for this unforgettable experience. I feel so privileged to have met such a cool captain and the amazing crew family who made me feel right at home. üíõ

This was D‚Ä¢Moment with Cpt. Charlotte @cha.johansen

D‚Ä¢Moment with Catherine in Calabria, Italy üáÆüáπ

From USA to Southern Italy's mountains, Catherine found solace in Badolato Borgo's quiet charm ( @badolatoslowvillage ). Retired nurse, tending plants outside her stone house, surrounded by stray cats. Neighbors say she's become part of the community, caring for flowers and feeding wild cats. Initially hesitant, she smiled warmly, reflecting kindness and new life.

Do you know someone with a great story to share? Tell me about them along with the location, I‚Äôd love to add it to my list, and who knows, maybe one day I‚Äôll be there to capture their beauty. Send me a DM or email (you can find it in my bio). Let‚Äôs spread some love everywhere.

When I asked his name, he replied, ‚ÄòI am Thor‚Äô‚ö°Ô∏è
Some people still joke that I met the real Norse God that day üòÖ

ImageLabels: img1 | img2 | img3 | img4 | img5 | img6 | img7
Caption:
D‚Ä¢Moment with Gerald in London üá¨üáß

Sometimes our facial expressions can lead others to form quick prejudices about us. A serious, preoccupied, or nervous look in a single moment might create a wrong perception, when in reality it‚Äôs just a fleeting state of mind.
In this series of portraits with Gerald, I wanted to capture exactly that kind of expression, because I felt it gave him character and strength. But going a bit further with more photo shoots, I also captured his genuine smile, his gentle demeanor, and the soft warmth of a man with so much love inside. To me, both sides are remarkable and poetic in their own way.
We all have many aspects of our lives reflected in our faces.

So, which shot speaks to you more, the serious, posed one or the smiley, relaxed one?

This girl has yellow eyes! And while most 18-year-olds chase trends or fame, Kajsa wants to be out there chasing fish. She told me this almost shyly, like she knew it‚Äôs not exactly what people expect from someone her age. She wants to be out on a fishing boat, pulling in kilometres of nets, getting covered in fish guts and seawater... and loving it. It‚Äôs gritty, it‚Äôs real, and honestly? It‚Äôs kind of badass. Not your average dream, but a seriously cool one. Big respect to Kajsa for following her own path, an inspiration for anyone who‚Äôs not afraid to do life a little differently. We really hope this D‚Ä¢Moment reaches the right people so they can hear your story and hire youü§ûüèª‚Ä®‚Ä®What about you? What crazy or unusual job did you dream of doing when you were her age?

Crew: @vanitaiuk

ImageLabels: img1 | img2 | img3 | img4 | img5 | img6 | img7
Caption:
You know, you feel you‚Äôre in the right place, at the right time, with the right subjects, and that‚Äôs when you know this is the moment you can‚Äôt let slip away. You have to capture it. This was one of those moments when life casually drops a movie scene right in front of you. This was D¬∑Moment I met Espen and his gorgeous Alaskan Malamute, Fenris, walking along the same path we were hiking in the beautiful countryside of Southern Norway. Espen looked like a Viking who had swapped his battle axe for a perfectly fitted sweater, and Fenris had that regal ‚Äúwolf prince‚Äù aura that made you stop and stare. Together, they moved with such harmony, the rolling fields behind them felt like a set built just for this shot. Honestly, it might have been one of the most naturally perfect photo shoots I‚Äôve ever stumbled upon.

What about you, what would you do in that moment? Would you just stand there in awe, approach them to ask for some photos, or even just tell them how cool they are? üì∏üê∫

ImageLabels: img1 | img2 | img3 | img4 | img5 | img6
Caption:
D‚Ä¢Moment with Udeme in NYC üóΩ

I met her just after she had finished a work interview, something she casually mentioned as we got to talking. Right away, there was a quiet confidence about her. She was calm, kind, and carried herself with a simplicity that felt genuine. Nothing flashy, just real.

During the shoot, there was this moment where she put on a pair of glasses, and it was surprising how something so small could shift a person‚Äôs look so much. It wasn‚Äôt just her appearance that changed, but the whole vibe she gave off, more focused, maybe even a bit sharper, yet still that same humble presence.

It reminded me how much of a story someone‚Äôs look can tell, especially when it‚Äôs effortless. Udeme didn‚Äôt need to try hard, she had that natural grace that speaks louder than words.

What do you think, with glasses or without? Which version catches your eye more? Drop a comment below, I‚Äôd love to hear your take!

ImageLabels: img1 | img2 | img3 | img4 | img5 | img6 | img7
Caption:
D‚Ä¢Moment with Dario Cecchini in Panzano üáÆüáπ

If there‚Äôs one person who comes to mind when I think of the true beauty of Italy, the kind that speaks straight to the heart, it‚Äôs Dario Cecchini. The Butcher. One of the most lovely, genuine, and warm souls I‚Äôve ever had the chance to meet.

Dario‚Äôs humble spirit, his boundless energy, and his deep love for people are something rare. The way he connects, entertains, and uplifts, with that rich, sincere voice and a soul as colorful as his style, feels like poetry in motion. He embodies what it means to give unconditionally.

The D‚Ä¢Moment with him wasn‚Äôt just about capturing an image. It was about experiencing a moment of pure authenticity. A reminder that when you pour your heart into something without expectation, the return can be something priceless: an unexpected friendship and a memory that stays with you forever.

@dariocecchinimacellaio

D‚Ä¢Moment with Maartje

In 2022, I had the pleasure of meeting Maartje in the Dubai desert during a @boss campaign, where I was invited to capture some of the celebrities and models. Portraying her was truly a joy, she was incredibly easy to talk to, with a gentle attitude and graceful movements that made the experience even more memorable.

ImageLabels: img1 | img2 | img3 | img4 | img5 | img6 | img7 | img8 | img9
Caption:
D‚Ä¢Moment for a Tango in Buenos Aires üá¶üá∑
with Cynddi & Matias üíÉüèºüï∫üèº

On a day of January 2024 I found myself wandering the streets of Buenos Aires, and out of nowhere, two tango dancers caught my eye. They weren‚Äôt just performing, they were connecting. Every step, every pause, felt like poetry in motion. I don‚Äôt know much about dance, let alone tango, but what I saw felt like watching a noir love story unfold without words.

There was intimacy, tension, grace‚Ä¶ something raw and real. It made me wonder how often we witness something truly human without realizing it.

Have you ever been moved by a moment like that, unexpected, beautiful, and quietly unforgettable? I‚Äôd love to hear about it in the comments üí¨
Let‚Äôs share some stories üíõ

D‚Ä¢Moment with Sondre ‚öíÔ∏è

He was probably the youngest boatbuilder I met during my photography journey across Norway in 2021. A remarkable young man with a real passion for crafting
boats

Which shot catches your attention more?

I met Jennifer on a tiny Arctic Island, her story may change how you see choices.
What started as a casual encounter quickly turned into something much deeper.
Her life journey, from a past of comfort and education to choosing a completely different, slower-paced life in the Arctic, was nothing short of eye-opening.
It made me wonder‚Ä¶
Would you ever leave behind everything you know for something totally different?
Could you trade the rush of your busy routine for peace, isolation, and simplicity?
Or maybe you‚Äôre already living a story like Jennifer‚Äôs?

Caption: Thank you so much to @saramaestrelli for the fabulous experience of @lapensioneamerica ! Caption: Its hard to write captions for photos that are so self-evident in their style and emotions for Italian Summer! Long skirts, shorts skirts, lace cover-ups and  boyfriend shirts all done so well! Forte dei Marmi

ImageLabels: img1 | img2 | img3 | img4 | img5 | img6 | img7 | img8 | img9 | img10 | img11 | img12 | img13 | img14 | img15
Caption: Forte dei Marmi is on fire! It really specializes in a certain casual beachy/city chic that I‚Äôve never seen or photographed in the Hamptons or Miami. I‚Äôm getting very curious about spending a little time in St Tropez !

ImageLabels: img1 | img2 | img3 | img4 | img5 | img6 | img7 | img8 | img9 | img10 | img11 | img12 | img13 | img14 | img15 | img16
Caption: First edition of ‚Äúintersections Forte dei Marmi, Italy 2025!‚Äù This past weekend was quite the parade in Forte! The first slide is self explanatory! Slide two is color! 3&4 are a great, real moment of being lost in thought but make it fashion! Slide 5 is the best sight at the end of the day and the rest are all great little moments as Italy gears up for summer break! FdM of course!

Caption: High summer and Milan is a mixed bag of style (but lucky so much good style!) these looks are all over the place with no clear trend or direction which ,I guess, it‚Äôs real tribute to personal style! And when you get to the photo of Anastasia just know she‚Äôs wearing shorts! Milano (of course)

ImageLabels: img1 | img2 | img3 | img4 | img5 | img6 | img7 | img8 | img9 | img10
Caption: Another chic July afternoon in Milano! Yesterday I thought it was going to be the summer of navy and black but by yesterday evening I‚Äôm think bold colors like slide 1, 3 and 4! I wonder if 5 has a bike to match every color skirt she has! 6 and 7 are a touch Boho Bali and 8-10 classic b/w! Milano (of course!)

ImageLabels: img1 | img2 | img3 | img4 | img5 | img6 | img7 | img8 | img9 | img10 | img11 | img12 | img13 | img14 | img15 | img16
Caption: Mid-Summer and some trends are very clear! The first section is all about navy and blue in soldi, stripes and prints! LWD (Little White Dress) is followed by the LBD (Little Black Dress) and then a few classic B/W looks. Curious to see the comments about slide 14! Slide 15(Anastasia‚Äôs favorite) & 16 are about color all-over prints! Milano (of course!)

ImageLabels: img1 | img2 | img3 | img4 | img5 | img6 | img7 | img8 | img9 | img10 | img11 | img12 | img13 | img14 | img15 | img16 | img17 | img18
Caption: Crazy weather the last few days but it helped to make a great assortment of styles to fight the windy, rain and/or heat! It seems this is the summer of white with pops of color or (like the green look, color on color on color) Milan (of course)

ImageLabels: img1 | img2 | img3 | img4 | img5 | img6 | img7 | img8 | img9 | img10
Caption: In the previous two years I didn‚Äôt start shooting at the intersections until July (basically bc no one wants to look at photos of people on bikes wearing coats!) However this year I couldn‚Äôt wait and it‚Äôs been really fun! So the fact that today is July 1st makes me really happy for another month of summer dresses, strappy sandals and Italian gentlemen in linen suits!  Anyway I really love the shots from last night especially the second image, she looks almost French in the subtly of the style, flared dark jeans and woven loafers (the whole look is very chic!) The fourth slide is quintessential Italian Summer! Milano (of course!)

ImageLabels: img1 | img2 | img3 | img4 | img5 | img6 | img7 | img8 | img9 | img10 | img11
Caption: Like eyelet or lace, fabrics with texture and surface dimension that also breath are a life-saver for summer! As we see in a great example in slide 1, a very dapper Milanese gentleman looks so cool in so hot Milan, I also really love seeing more men wearing the Tiffany bone-bracelet like in slide 9! Thanks Milan (of course!)

ImageLabels: img1 | img2 | img3 | img4 | img5 | img6 | img7 | img8 | img9 | img10
Caption: Back to Milano! It‚Äôs hot here but it seems to be hot everywhere! So I‚Äôve had the debate with several people. They say riding a bike to work makes them too sweaty, I feel exactly the opposite unless you work at a castle on top of a hill! I‚Äôve ridden both electric and normal bikes for years and I find them much more freshing than a humid subway or less taxing than walking in heat! I think that first slide is the dream everyone has of wind flowing through your clothes and hair and arriving at work like a Botticelli ( but with clothes on!) Milano (of course!)

ImageLabels: img1 | img2 | img3 | img4 | img5 | img6 | img7 | img8 | img9 | img10 | img11 | img12 | img13 | img14 | img15 | img16 | img17 | img18 | img19
Caption: A quick but very fruitful trip to Paris! I know I should have gone to more shows but the streets of Le Marais wouldn‚Äôt let me go! I don‚Äôt usually post more than one image of a person but yesterday I kept photographing such great style paired with such charming gestures that I decided to let myself indulge just a little! Fingers crossed that today is equally exciting! Thanks Paris

ImageLabels: img1 | img2 | img3 | img4 | img5 | img6 | img7 | img8 | img9 | img10
Caption: Oh my! The first three could all lead a post because they are so good but how could I not post a woman wearing white gloves to bicycle as the first look! I love the draping of the second dress but it might be just a happy coincidence of wind! The third look is ALL about the accessories! The men are chic ,as usual, but very different in their approach to style! I really look forward to shooting this all month!

ImageLabels: img1 | img2 | img3 | img4 | img5 | img6 | img7 | img8 | img9 | img10 | img11 | img12 | img13 | img14 | img15 | img16 | img17 | img18 | img19 | img20
Caption: So much great vintage Prada at the Prada men‚Äôs show today! The women looked great (as per usual!) but the men‚Äôs editors and buyers looked so much cooler than the influencers plus the editors were dressed in season-appropriate clothes not wool coats and furs  like the influencers üßê anyway what a great way to spend a City Sunday in Milano

ImageLabels: img1 | img2 | img3 | img4 | img5 | img6 | img7 | img8 | img9 | img10 | img11 | img12 | img13 | img14 | img15 | img16 | img17 | img18
Caption: One of the strongest Pitti posts I‚Äôve ever done! Super chic women!  Very handsome men! Great unique style on every slide! It‚Äôs getting hard to find the gems at Pitti but they‚Äôre still there and they‚Äôre worth the effort! Thanks Firenze for another wonderful Pitti

ImageLabels: img1 | img2 | img3 | img4 | img5 | img6 | img7 | img8 | img9
Caption:
1 million people ü•≤

I used to be a student dreaming of making a living through photography ‚Äî of traveling the world, discovering new cultures, and finding the courage to talk to strangers.

Then I spent a year working a 9‚Äì5 job in finance, holding on to the dream of escaping and truly living ‚Äî of seeing the world with my own eyes.

and here we are now, 1 million people acknowledging my work ü•≤

I wish I could tell that younger Bleg that he‚Äôs on the right path.
That his shyness is actually his strength.
That the voice he used to hate would one day be the reason people connect with him.
That real connections come when the time is right.
and that everything is possible if you put your heart to it

To everyone I‚Äôve photographed, to everyone I‚Äôve met on the path, to everyone who follows the journey ‚Äî thank you ü§ç

I promise to always stay true to my values and to keep going as long as my heart tells me to

I don‚Äôt care about being famous. I don‚Äôt care about the money.
What matters is that I feel peace within, and that I stay aligned with what feels right.

Thank you to my family and friends who always encouraged me ü•≤
Thank you @oe_glitter for being the first person I ever approached that way ü§ç
Thank you @papesan for giving advices when I needed the most ü§ç
Thank you @jenybsg for encouraging me to take the leap and quit my job ü§ç
Thank you to my mom and my brother, who gave me the money to buy my first camera 

And thank you ‚Äî whoever‚Äôs reading this right now.
I wish you nothing but health, peace, and happiness ü§ç

The journey has just begun 

with Love, 

Bleg

"Dunes Like You", Dubai, 2016 // Photo: ¬© Scarlett Hooft Graafland

Scarlett Hooft Graafland is a Dutch visual artist known for her dreamlike, site-specific photographs that blend performance, sculpture, and landscape. 

In "Dunes Like You" (2016), taken in the deserts of Dubai, she places a group of figures draped in vibrant fabrics across an expanse of sand, their forms echoing the curves of the surrounding dunes, resulting is a surreal and poetic composition that blurs the line between nature and the human presence within it.

Caption:
Image of the Day üì∏‚Å†

"Rush", Kolkata, India // Photo: ¬© Marius Burgelman / @mariusburgelman_

This striking photograph by Brussels-based photographer Marius Burgelman, selected as an Editor's Pick in our Street Photography award this Spring, depicts a moment of life on the frenetic streets of Kolkata, capturing the tension between motion and stillness beautifully. 

At its center, a yellow taxi‚Äîemblematic of the city‚Äîsits unmoved, its driver meeting the viewer‚Äôs gaze with an arresting calm, while around him, the figures of passersby dissolve into streaks of motion, rendered ghostlike by a slow shutter speed. The composition becomes a visual metaphor for urban life itself: fleeting and relentless, yet punctuated by moments of quiet clarity and connection.

Caption:
Image of the Day üì∏‚Å†

Bronx, NYC, C. 1970s // Photo: ¬© Camilo Jos√© Vergara / @nodrybones

Camilo Jos√© Vergara is a pioneering photographer and sociologist whose images of 1970s New York City form one of the most important visual records of urban America in decline. 

With a systematic approach more akin to sociology than traditional photojournalism, he documented the crumbling infrastructure, abandoned buildings, and resilient communities of neighborhoods like the South Bronx, Harlem, and Bushwick‚Äîat a time when many had written them off entirely.

Rather than sensationalize, Vergara sought to understand. His photographs, often shot in stark natural light and composed with unflinching directness, reflect a deep respect for place and people. They are not just images of decay, but of endurance‚Äîbearing witness to cycles of neglect and renewal, and challenging the viewer to confront uncomfortable truths about race, poverty, and urban policy.
‚Å†.‚Å†
.‚Å†

Caption:
Image of the Day üì∏‚Å†
‚Å†
Czechoslovakia, 1968 // Photo: ¬© Josef Koudelka / @josef_koudelka

Taken during the Warsaw Pact invasion of Czechoslovakia in 1968, this surreal and haunting image by Czech photographer Josef Koudelka captures a fleeting, fragile moment of innocence amid the chaos of political upheaval. A young boy, dressed in makeshift angel wings, rides a bicycle through an empty street, a silent figure caught between fantasy and reality, peace and oppression.

Shot with Koudelka‚Äôs signature immediacy and intuitive framing, the image is rich in symbolism. The wings evoke purity and vulnerability, while the stark urban backdrop hints at a world that has lost its innocence. It‚Äôs a quietly powerful reminder of the personal, human dimension of historical trauma, and a testament to Koudelka‚Äôs ability to find poetry in the most unlikely places.
.‚Å†
.‚Å†
.
.
.‚Å†

Caption:
Image of the Day üì∏‚Å†
‚Å†
Man and Taj Reflection, India, 1999 // Photo: ¬© Steve McCurry / @stevemccurryofficial

True to his obsessive drive to document the social landscapes of his time, Steve McCurry‚Äîarmed with both a real passport and a metaphorical one‚Äîhas helped shape the visual narratives of numerous countries. Yet, it is India that has remained the cornerstone of his artistic journey. It was here, as a young man not long out of university, that he laid the foundations of his practice. Since then, he has returned frequently, capturing breathtaking images of its landscapes, people, and daily life, photographs that remain among the most iconic in his extraordinary oeuvre.
‚Å†.‚Å†
.‚Å†

Caption:
‚ÄúThere‚Äôs a certain magic in being able to freeze those fleeting moments, to immortalize the raw, unfiltered essence of humanity.‚Äù

Monaris is a Puerto Rican-born, New Jersey-based photographer, known for her captivating depictions of everyday life in NYC and beyond.

While the term ‚Äúcinematic‚Äù is often overused, it perfectly describes Monaris‚Äôs work. Heavily influenced by directors and filmmakers, and captures fleeting moments that often evade the attention of the throngs, creating images that reveal but a fragment of a larger tale, inviting the viewer to ponder the hidden stories beneath.

Wed. 2/14‚Ä¶ Dear Grandma, I lost you 7 years ago today. It makes a certain amount of sense for you to be with God on Valentine‚Äôs Day. Your name, Zohra, in Arabic means a flower blossom. I miss you so much, Muyma. You raised 5 sons, and I was extra credit. You‚Äôd be proud of the man I‚Äôve become. I try to make people happy every day in our home city.

Caption:
It‚Äôs 10 minutes before kick-off. I‚Äôve just met @kevinhart4real and edited/posted a reel on the spot. The views are going crazy. I‚Äôm packing up my equipment at Xfinity live.

A girl sitting nearby tips her 40oz beer, and it gets all over my laptop and camera. I‚Äôm panicking. What do I do now? I don‚Äôt even have a press pass to get into the stadium. Every high-level contact I have says there‚Äôs nothing they can do.

I wipe everything down, pack up my bag, and start walking towards the Linc. My mother would always say, ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs the worst they can say? No.‚Äù Let me just see what they say.

Headphones playing Dreams & Nightmares by @meekmill full-blast on repeat. I feel the spirit of my grandmother who raised me in the sky & wind. Holding back tears I get to the gate.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm South Street Sam.‚Äù They let me in. It was the will of God.
.
.
.
.

Caption:

Gratitude, openness, and a steady flow of positive energy will draw this future self into your present reality. Life is magical, and you are the magician of your own life. Awaken to your true, eternal, divine self‚Äîheal within, and live from a space of abundance.

Caption: Prioritizing your inner peace is the first step towards inner awakening. Inner peace leads to external peace, and as you align within, you shall project outwardly. Reflect on your mind patterns layer by layer and heal within. As you become aware of your patterns, respond to them with love and acceptance. Accept those layers of learning and let go of the urge to impulsively let them trigger you; free yourself from unconscious self-sabotaging habits. The healer within you rises to resolve all projections of duality, and you awaken to your true source within. The quest of spirituality is undertaken within the vessel of your infinite inner self. Caption: True peace doesn‚Äôt come from closing your eyes or escaping your circumstances. It arises from realizing the source of existence - your deeper self. When you tap into that source, unlearning happens naturally, and the mind frees itself from duality. The inward journey is about remembering who you truly are. From that space, only compassion and oneness flow outward. At first, it may feel unfamiliar, but with practice, your being becomes rooted in joy, peace, and effortless presence. It takes a million steps to wander outward, but only one step taken now - to return within.

Caption:
True richness of the heart is measured by the depth of empathy one holds for oneself and all of existence. The light of higher frequencies can only flow through a heart that remains open. A heart that surrenders to the divine will yet carries compassion for others will always be at peace.
To be at peace is to embrace both past and present as threads of a greater plan. One day, looking back, it will all make sense but for now, the path unfolds only by moving forward in surrender. To surrender is to fully embrace your emotions without resistance, allowing them to flow freely rather than suppressing them. In return, this deep acceptance brings forth an eternal stillness within. In the present moment, we come to realize our true inner essence, witnessing the divine play unfold through our existence.

Caption: To be in love with yourself is to be in love with existence itself. Once you fill your cup with joy and eternal inner love, that love flows outward with grace. If an external situation shakes you, the only thing that will drip from your inner self is peace and acceptance. Self-love transcends the boundaries of hatred; as you begin treating yourself with empathy, you respond to triggers instead of reacting to them. The peace of existence begins with your own internal peace. If you wish to bring about world peace, start with your own heart. Call upon the peace within your soul, and let it radiate outward. Abundance flows right behind you in this space of oneness and grace of stillness takes over your being to open up the gate of divine within.

Caption:
üò± I gave a pilot üßë‚Äç‚úàÔ∏è a disposable camera üì∏ 

My interview with @pepethepilot when he came back to LA to gave me back the disposable camera. 

Me: my dream was always to be a pilot üßë‚Äç‚úàÔ∏è why did you become a pilot üßë‚Äç‚úàÔ∏è? 

Jose pilot:  when people get on a plane ‚úàÔ∏è it‚Äôs always a big life changing moment.  I fly out of the country, so most people who are in the plane with me are making life changes decisions. People who are moving, seeing a loved one, going to start a brand new life in a new country. I liked to believe that I am their guide who has been given the responsibility to safely transport these people to their new beginnings.  These people‚Äôs lives are in my hands and I take that very seriously. With love we will safely get them to their new homes üè† ü´Çüßë‚Äç‚úàÔ∏è

 I can‚Äôt believe @pepethepilot took the camera. I am so honored.  So much respect for you my brother! My new friend.

Caption:
I was strolling the streets of Munich with the Leica M6 again. üî¥ And with analog photography, every shot matters because it costs. üí∏ Do again, I challenged myself to capture only three photos per session! üì∏

I ran into a lovely couple: Sabrina and Justin and they agreed to click a few portraits. Guess what? It was Sabrina's birthday! üéâ Of course, I had to sing her a little birthday song. üé∂ Good that I'm a photographer, not a singer. üòÇ Thank you @sabrinaabiancaa and @jstnlky for your trust and for such a beautiful encounter!

Caption:
Three shots portrait challenge! üì∏ Took my friend's stunning Leica M6 for a spin in Munich, capturing street style portraits. When I spotted Kean waiting for his girlfriend, I was instantly drawn to his cool vibe. To my surprise, Kean was just as intrigued by my camera as I was by his style. It turns out, he's also a fan of analog photography! üéûÔ∏è What a beautiful coincidence ‚ú®

What I absolutely love about shooting film: It's all about focus and intention. Every shot counts, and every photo is precious. Have you ever tried shooting on film? Share your thoughts below in the comments üëá‚ú®

Check his amazing tattoo work on his IG @keanmendez
Hashtags: FilmPhotography | LeicaM6 | HappyClicking | streetphotography | styleclicker | streetportrait | photographer | portraitphotography | photographingstrangers | analogvibes | FilmIsNotDead | WhatMakesYouHappy | creativity

Caption:
üåü What a beautiful name: Laure. üåü

Picture this: an early evening in Milan, and there she was, sitting on a stone bench, lost in her book. Her effortlessly cool, casual look caught my eye, and I just had to capture the moment. üì∏

I approached her, explained that I'm a street style photographer, and asked if I could take a few more portraits. To my surprise, she was a bit taken aback, thinking she wasn't looking her best that day. But trust me, she looked amazing! üòç

Turns out, Laure is not only into photography but also works as a model. It was one of those magical encounters that make street photography so rewarding. 

Thank you, Laure, for trusting me and letting me capture your essence. It was such a pleasure to meet you! üôå‚ú®

Make sure to check her Instagram @ruedelor ü§©
Hashtags: streetphotography | styleclicker | streetportrait | photographer | streetstyle | photography | portraitphotography | photographingstrangers | strangerphotography | analogvibes

Caption:
Happiness isn't a destination; it's a journey! üåü We often think happiness is a state of being, but it's actually a process. When we grow, we glow! ‚ú® Remember that first leap off the five-meter tower? 

We might believe that happiness will stick around forever, but it's more like a flowing river, constantly moving and evolving. 
It's all about the process of doing and creating, and seeing the results of our efforts. That's why diving into creative activities brings us so much joy. It comes from what we do‚Äîwhether it's photography, painting, football, or music. üé∂ Music is the perfect metaphor: it's fluid, here one moment and gone the next, yet it fills us with joy. 

Let's embrace this journey together and find happiness in our creative process! üì∏üé®‚öΩüé∂
Hashtags: Happiness | CreativeSelfcare | StreetPhotography | HappyClicking | photography | styleclicker | portraitphotography | streetvideos | selfcare | creativity

Caption:
Stumbled upon magic in Malm√∂! üåü Mikala and Maria made a spontaneous day trip from Copenhagen, and I was lucky enough to cross paths with them while capturing street portraits. Their style and vibe were absolutely captivating, and I couldn't resist asking for a photo. Grateful they said yes! üôå

These two are the epitome of cool, and Maria's impromptu dance while I was checking the shots was the cherry on top of an unforgettable encounter. ü§© Thank you both, Mikala and Maria, for your trust and time‚Äîyou truly made my day! üì∏‚ú®

Encounters like these are what make street photography so special. Feeling grateful and inspired! ‚ù§Ô∏è
Hashtags: streetphotography | styleclicker | streetportrait | photographer | streetstyle | photography | portraitphotography | photographingstrangers | strangerphotography | analogvibes

Caption:
Ever wondered what camera setup I use for my street videos? ü§î It's a question I get all the time, so here's the scoop! When I'm out there capturing those candid moments, I need a camera that's unobtrusive and lets me keep my hands free for my photo camera. Enter the GoPro Hero 8 Black! üì∏‚ú®

Why do I love it? The image quality and stabilization are top-notch, and the sound quality is so good I don't even need an external mic. The only downside? Battery life. Usually, I carry 5-6 batteries with me. üîãü§™

My secret weapon? The GoPro chest mount! Just flip out the levers of your GoPro, screw it to the chest mount and you're good to go. I even wear a jacket over it for extra stealth mode. Almost looks like a fashion piece, right? üòâ

I always have my trusty backpack with me for all my gear. That's my setup in a nutshell! Got more questions? Drop them in the comments, and I'll be happy to answer. Thanks for tuning in, and happy clicking! üì∑üí•

Caption:
What would I advice a young artist or photo artist or whatever to do, is to just start working. Don‚Äôt get stuck, don‚Äôt overthink It, go out start working, make mistakes, your work will be crap at first; It‚Äôs fine my work every time I start something new Is junk, absolute junk. I have to throw away so many photographs and I‚Äôm embarrassed and thank God you will not see them, nobody will see them but just wade through It, just keep going, and In the case of photography you know sooner or later the world will whisper In your ear and say let me show you something far more interesting than your little Idea, let me show you a much better way of dealing with the world, of seeing the world, so but you have to prepared to listen, to be out there and working and listening, It will come, you just have to keep going and keep at It, make mistakes make errors, get through the bad work, and then the good work arrives. Just look for It. It will arrive.

Paul Graham Gives Advice to the Young Photographers by Louisiana YouTube Channel
